well unlike

human
nature
and I think that our sort of
psychological

so for example the sence of

think that's that's one of the places
that I start but I think I also want to
say that because of how I think about
our psychologies I think that it's
crucial to recognize that um the
institutional context in which people
live makes a huge difference again as to
what their possibilities are um I've
never committed a serious crime I'm
pretty certain that if I'd lived and
been raised in certain kinds of
environments I would have committed a
serious crime by now so I've been lucky
to live in an environment which hasn't
made committing serious crimes um an
attractive option for me or one that I
could sort of live with
psychologically you know it follows from
that that you want to make a world in
which nobody is in the situation uh
which would tempt anybody to commit a
crime uh there are I think people uh we
we call them Psychopaths or sociopaths
there are people who who may be more
easily tempted to those things in normal
circumstances and so we need to keep an
eye out for them but most people won't
commit crimes if they're uh if they have
reasonable amount of resources and a in
a family that loves them and a community
that makes sense to them and and you
know a decent police force so uh so I
think looking back on history reinforces
for me both the Persistence of human
nature and the importance of
institutions the importance of
organizing the world in ways that
respect our natures and allow us to do
given our Natures uh to to lead good
